National Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory University of Science and Technology of China Hefei Anhui 230029 PR China Harmful carbon monoxide (CO) gas from vehicle exhaust and fossil fuel combustion seriously affects the ecological environment and human health, although this issue can be effectively solved by low-temperature catalytic combustion. Herein, an Fe and N codoped double vacancy graphene catalyst (Fe-CxNy) for the low-temperature catalytic combustion of CO is proposed, and the mechanism of the CO catalytic combustion reaction over the catalyst is systematically investigated by using density function theory (DFT). Four oxidation mechanisms, including Eley–Rideal (ER1 and ER2), Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) and Termolecular Eley–Rideal (TER), were compared in terms of oxidation pathways and energy distribution. All the results indicate that Fe-CxNy catalysts have efficient catalytic activity. The Fe-CN3 catalyst with the predominant LH reaction mechanism showed the best performance for the catalytic combustion of CO with only 0.20 eV, which was comparable to that of noble metals. The rate constant calculations further demonstrate that Fe-CN3 exhibits excellent catalytic performance at low temperatures. This work not only provides a theoretical basis for the design and development of low-temperature catalytic combustion CO catalysts, but also provides data support for the kinetic model of CO combustion reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO oxidation Nitrogen coordination Graphene Catalytic combustion Single-atom catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide gas comes from automobile exhaust, industrial exhaust, household gas stoves, hydrocarbon fuel combustion, etc. [1–4]. CO pollutes the ecological environment that human beings depend on, and threatens people's health. The colorless and odorless nature of CO means that it is often undetectable and that the leakage of CO easily cause poisoning [5,6]. It has been reported in the literature that the survival time of organisms will not exceed 3 min when the concentration of CO exceeds 12,800 ppm [7]. CO can react photochemically with nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds to form atmospheric pollutants and damage the environment [8,9]. Understanding the carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation mechanism is beneficial for the development of catalysts for the synergistic control of NOx and CO. There are two solutions to CO pollutants. The first is to solve the emergence of CO at the source. Incomplete combustion of fossil energy is widely believed to be the main pathway for the production of CO. Demand for fossil energy (80% of total energy [10]) is still strong today, with its consumption inevitably generating large amounts of CO. Therefore, people have been trying to use clean energy, such as hydrogen energy, solar energy, and biomass energy, to replace fossil energy sources [11–15]. The second solution to CO pollutants is to eliminate. Both physical and chemical methods are commonly used to eliminate CO. Physical methods utilizese porous materials to achieve physical adsorption, which has the disadvantages of low efficiency and high cost, and can cause secondary pollution to the environment. In contrast, the chemical method involves oxidizing CO to CO2 by a catalyst, an application most widely used in industrial production and automotive exhaust [16,17]. Recently, although car manufacturers have been encouraged to shift from fuel to new energy vehicles, it is expected that vehicles on the road will still be predominantly driven by internal combustion engines by approximately 2050 [18]. Improvements in technologies related to internal combustion engines are necessary to reduce pollutants such as soot and dust. With increasing attention to the ecological environment, all countries have formulated corresponding carbon emission regulations, striving to seek development in green ecology and protect the ecological environment in development. Therefore, catalytic combustion of CO is of great significance [19]. Catalysts commonly mentioned for the combustion of CO are mainly conventional catalysts based on precious metals, such as Pd [20,21], Au [22,23], Pt [24,25], Ru [26,27], and Rh [28,29]. The fact that these catalysts are scarce limits their application even more [30], which has led to a wide interest in transition metals, including metal oxides and SACs [19,31]. Due to their low energy barrier, high stability and high atomic utilization [32], SACs exhibit excellent catalytic performance in various important reactions, such as water electrolysis [33], CO2 electroreduction and CO oxidation [34]. The concept of monatomic catalysts first appeared in 2011 and was proposed by Zhang and his colleagues [35]. SAC supports mainly include metal oxides (Al2O3 [36], ZrO2 [37], CeO2 [38], etc.) and two-dimensional materials (graphene [39,40], boron nitride [41], MoS2 [42], etc.). Two-dimensional materials have attracted much attention because of their high thermal stability, large specific surface area and low preparation cost. Graphene is a typical two-dimensional material, that has excellent thermal conductivity, large current density and good ductility, and has been widely used in the field of material catalysis [43–47]. Graphene doped with single atoms is reported to have good CO-catalytic properties. Jiang and colleagues found that the CO oxidation barrier of Al-doped graphene is only 0.32 eV, which is larger than that of Au-doped graphene (0.31 eV) [48,49]. Li and his coworkers [50] calculated the barrier of Fe-doped mono-defect graphene for CO (0.58 eV). This system has a higher energy barrier, which is not favorable for CO combustion, and the catalyst activity needs to be improved. Previous studies have shown that the catalytic ability of the catalyst can be effectively improved by adding heteroatoms (N, P, S). The reaction energy barrier of a single N-doped Pd atom loaded on graphene is only 0.25 eV [51]. Fe atoms are the most active catalysts for CO oxidation among the 14 transition metals studied in the N-doped graphene system [52]. More interestingly, many studies have reported the preparation of Fe-N-C series catalysts, which have been applied in benzene oxidation [53]. However, previous studies have focused on mono-vacancy graphene more than divacancy graphene. There are few reports exploring the effects of coordination environments on CO by controlling different concentrations of nitrogen-doped graphene [53–55]. In this work, an efficient nonprecious metal catalyst for CO catalytic combustion is proposed. We systematically investigate the CO combustion reaction mechanism of double-defective Fe-CxNy in different coordination environments by ab initio calculations and select the optimal reaction path. Moreover, the rate constant study and ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations are helpful for the simulation of real CO catalytic combustion. This work demonstrates that the catalytic performance of the catalyst can be effectively improved by reasonable adjustment of the coordination environment, which provides a theoretical basis for the design and development of advanced CO catalysts. 2 Theoretical methods All calculations in this work were performed by the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP version 5.4.4) [56–58]. In the generalized gradient approximation formulation, Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [59] is used to exchange correlation functionals for structural relaxation and energy minimization. The DFT-D3 [60] method of Grimme's scheme was used to correct for van der Waals interactions present between the reactants and the support. Meanwhile, the projector augmented wave (PAW) [61] method was used for interactions between valence electrons and the core. The Kohn-Sham valence states expand in the plane-wave basis set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 500 eV [62]. The model taken in this work is a 4 × 4 × 1 graphene supercell with a total of 32 atoms. The double-defect graphene structure is obtained by hollowing out two adjacent carbons, which then carry Fe atoms and connect with 4 adjacent C or N atoms. Fe-CxNy means Fe is coordinated with x C atoms and y N atoms. In this article, we selected four coordination structures of Fe-C3N, Fe-C2N2, Fe-CN3 and Fe-N4, and the corresponding structure is shown in Fig. S1. FeC2N2 has three configurations, FeN2C2-pen, FeN2C2-opp and FeN2C2‑hex [63–65]. Configurations that have been successfully synthesized and applied to the oxidation mechanism are mostly Fe-C2N2-opp [53]. The vacuum layer thickness in the Z direction is 15 Å to avoid layer-to-layer interactions. The Brillouin zone was sampled at 3 × 3 × 1 and 6 × 6 × 1 for structural optimization and density of states calculations, respectively. In all relaxations, the maximum residual force for structure optimization is set to 0.01 eV/Å, and the energy convergence is 10−5 eV per atom. The transition state (TS) is calculated by dimer methods [66]. A negative frequency is formed during bond breaking or formation. The geometry of the transition state will be determined by the virtual vibrational frequency. We calculated the energy barriers of the four models under different ER, LH and TER mechanisms and plotted the reaction paths from the initial state (IS) to the TS and finally to the final state (FS). The adsorption energy can be calculated by the following formula: (1) E ads = E adsorb − sub − ( E adsorb + E sub ) where Eads represents the adsorption energy, Eadsorb-sub represents the energy of the substrate and the adsorbate, Esub represents the energy of the substrate, and Eadsorb represents the energy of the adsorbed gas. The larger the value of Eads, the stronger the adsorption capacity of the substrate to the adsorbate. Through energy-barrier calculations, the most suitable reaction mechanism of CO over the Fe-CxNy catalyst was found. The energy barrier and heat of reaction can be calculated by: (2) E a = E TS − E IS (3) Δ E a = E FS − E IS where ETS represents the total energy of the transition state and EIS represents the energy of the initial state. A lower energy barrier indicates that the reaction needs to cross fewer obstacles and is more likely to occur. The Gibbs free energy at a specific temperature is calculated from ΔG = ΔEa + ΔGcorr , where ΔG corr is the free energy dependence at zero point energy, obtained by vibration frequency analysis. The reaction rate constant k is calculated from the harmonic transition state and is obtained by the following equation: (4) k = k B T h Q TS Q R exp [ − E a k B T ] where kB, h and T represent the Boltzmann constant, Planck constant and thermodynamic temperature, respectively. QTS and QR are the partition functions, which represent the transition state and reactants, respectively. The partition functions can be calculated by the following definition. (5) Q = 1 ∏ i = 1 vibration [ 1 − exp ( − h ν i k BT ) ] where νi is the frequency and the imaginary frequency of the transition state is not considered. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural properties of single Fe atoms loaded on graphene The binding energy is closely related to the stability of double-defective iron atoms loaded on graphene. The smaller the binding energy, the more stable it is. According to the literature we know that the binding energy of double-defective Fe loading on graphene is −8.29 eV, which is much smaller than the experimental and calculated value of Fe atoms [67,68]. This indicates that the structure of the catalyst of this system is stable. The electronegativity between Fe, C and N atoms is different. In Table 1 , the Fe-N structure causes charge transfer between Fe and N-modified graphene, thus improving the electron transfer capacity between the active site and the carbon carrier during CO oxidation. It should be feasible to get a model of this work from the table. The yellow color in the charge density diagram in Fig. 1 (a) represents an increase in charge and the blue color represents a decrease in charge. Many charges are gathered by Fec and Fen bonds, and Fe provides electrons, indicating that it can be used as the active center. According to the Bader charge analysis, the charge of the N atom increases significantly as the number of N coordination sites increases, which is a greater electronegativity of the N atom than the C atom. In addition, the density of states is important for understanding the electronic structure of the catalyst. Fig. 1(b) shows the partial density of states plots for the four structures with Fermi energy level of 0. As seen from the figure, the d orbitals of Fe and the p orbitals of C or N appear to overlap in the energy range of −10 to 6 eV, which proves the existence of strong interactions between Fe atoms and C or N atoms. Notably, the intensity of the hybridization peaks appearing near the Fermi energy level becomes stronger as the number of N coordinations increases. We also calculated the D-band centers for different structures. D-band center theory suggests that the adsorption capacity is stronger as ɛd gets closer to the Fermi energy level. This is in general agreement with our adsorption energy results. The charge difference and density of states of the other three N-coordination catalysts are shown in Fig. S2. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations can further verify the structural stability of the Fe-CxNy catalyst. The structural and energy changes of the catalyst at 1000 K for the initial state, 200 fs, 400 fs, 600 fs, 800 fs, and 1000 fs are illustrated in Fig. 2 . Fe-CN3 has the smallest energy fluctuation range with increasing temperature and slight deformation of the atomic structure, indicating that the Fe-CN3 catalyst has a more stable structure. 3.2 Adsorption of O2, CO, O and CO2 on Fe-CxNy Before studying the mechanism of the CO combustion reaction, we first investigated the adsorption properties of different gases on Fe-CxNy, including O2, CO, O and CO2. All the adsorption energies and electron transfers are summarized in Table S1. In Fig. 3 (a), (b), the adsorption configuration of Fe-CN3 on the gas is similar to that of Fe-C3N and Fe-C2N2. Adsorbed O2 molecules tended to be parallel to the substrate and the OO bond was extended from 1.23 Å to 1.36 Å. Fe interacts with O to form two new FeO bonds, with lengths of 1.99 Å and 1.79 Å. O2 (0.59 |e|) and CO (0.18 |e|) transfer electrons to Fe-CN3. The p-orbital of the adsorbate and the d-orbital of Fe have overlapping peaks in the range of −10∼6 eV, indicating that the adsorbate can be activated on Fe atoms. Adsorption of O2 and CO by Fe-CN3 was chemisorbed with adsorption energies of −1.19 eV and −1.64 eV, respectively. We found that the adsorption energies of O2 and CO on Fe-N4 were −0.80 eV and −1.58 eV, respectively (Fig. 3(c), (d)), which means that the adsorption capacity of O2 in the Fe-CxNy system gradually decreases with increasing the N coordination number. Therefore, the adsorption configuration of O2 on Fe-N4 is different from that before. It will interact with Fe at a larger tilt angle, resulting in FeO bonds. The different selectivity and adsorption configuration of the catalyst to the adsorbate will inevitably affect its catalytic activity and oxidation mechanism. For complete recovery of the catalyst, the properties of carbon dioxide adsorption on the catalyst were also investigated. The most stable adsorption conformation is shown in Fig. S4. We found that the adsorption energies of CO2 in Fe-CxNy are −0.18, −0.18, −0.19 and −0.18 eV, respectively, with constant shape and CO bond length. In Fe-CxNy, the distances from Fe atoms to O atoms are 2.85, 2.79, 2.86 and 2.96 Å, respectively, indicating that there is a weak interaction between CO2 and the carrier. CO2 has a rather small adsorption energy and is physically adsorbed. Theoretically, when the adsorption energy is less than −0.50 eV, the formed CO2 material will be automatically released at room temperature, which is favorable for the oxidation of CO on Fe-CxNy. Meanwhile, we calculated the adsorption conformation of O atoms on Fe-CxNy (as shown in Fig. S5). O atoms tend to adsorb vertically on Fe-Top. Weak adsorption of single-atom O on Fe-CxNy with increasing N coordination number, makes the FeO bond length longer. This provides a basis for the design of the CO oxidation pathway. In this work, the adsorption energy of CO is slightly stronger than that of O2. When both gases are coinjected, CO is preferentially adsorbed on the catalyst, which in turn promotes the oxidation process of CO, affecting the adsorption behavior and reaction path of the second molecule (O2 or CO). Fig. S6 shows the coadsorption configuration of CO and O2 on Fe-CxNy with a larger coadsorption energy than when O2 or CO is adsorbed alone, suggesting a possible LH mechanism for the catalyst in an environment with relatively flat CO and O2 concentrations. With a much higher CO adsorption energy of Fe-N4 (−1.58 eV) than its O2 adsorption energy (−0.80 eV), the Fe-N4 system prefers to adsorb two CO molecules rather than O2 and CO coadsorption, which is consistent with the theoretical calculations. As shown in Fig. S7, the adsorption energy of two CO at Fe-CxNy is stronger than that of O2 and CO and forms the intermediate structure of OCOOCO on Fe-CxNy with adsorption energies of −2.52, −2.74, −1.77 and −1.0 eV. The larger adsorption energies indicate that the catalyst is more desirable for the TER mechanism in environments with high CO concentrations. 3.3 Mechanism of CO oxidation on Fe-CxNy The oxidation reaction of CO with O2 is usually carried out by ER, LH and MvK, and the recently proposed TER has also been widely studied. 3.3.1 ER1 mechanism Based on the above analysis, although the interaction of the catalyst with CO is stronger than that with O2, the active center of the catalyst can be presorbed by O2 in an O2 rich environment. Therefore, we investigated the ER mechanism on Fe-CxNy. The ER1 mechanism can be expressed by the following two equations: (6) CO+O2*→CO2+O* (7) O*+CO→CO2 By overcoming a certain energy barrier during ER1, the free CO attacks the O2 preadsorbed on Fe-CxNy to form free CO2 and the adsorbed O atom. Then the second CO molecule approaches O* to form a second CO2, which completes the catalyst cycle. Conformations of physisorbed CO around the preadsorbed O2 are considered to be IS, while physisorbed CO2 and chemisorbed O atoms are considered to be FS (see Fig. 4 (a)). The total potential barrier for the reaction of CO with preadsorbed O2 to form the transition state (TS) is 0.79 eV. An energy of 3.50 eV is released by this reaction process, indicating that the ER1 mechanism of Fe-C3N is feasible. With the remaining one O atom being adsorbed on the Fe atom, the attack of the second CO molecule is awaited (Fig. S8(a)). This step of the reaction has an energy barrier of 0.70 eV and releases 1.46 eV of energy, which is comparable to the energy barrier of the first step of the reaction. Noticeably, however, the heat released from the first reaction step can overcome the energy barrier required for the second reaction step, which in turn can overcome the energy barrier of the first reaction and provide conditions for the CO catalytic oxidation cycle. In Fig. 4(b), the activated O2 on Fe-C2N2 is bonded to CO and the OO bond length is extended from 1.37 Å to 1.53 Å. After overcoming a potential barrier of 0.78 eV the OO bond breaks and then the C atom of CO combines with the dangling O atom to form CO2. The remaining adsorbed O atom reacts with the subsequent CO and the energy barrier from IS to FS is 0.70 eV. The adsorbed O atom reaction pathway is shown in Fig. S8(b). A similar bond length change to Fe-C2N2 is shown in Fig. 4(c) for the ER1 reaction path of Fe-CN3. The CO oxidation process only needs to overcome a potential barrier of 0.69 eV, releasing a reaction energy of 3.37 eV, which is smaller compared to Fe-C3N and Fe-C2N2. The second CO2 is finally obtained by crossing a small energy barrier of 0.42 eV (see Fig. S8(c)). Having a distance of 2.86 Å from the Fe atom, CO2 has a small adsorption energy (−0.19 eV) and can be desorbed at room temperature. In Fig. 4(d), IS differs from the above in that O2 is bonded to the Fe-atom of Fe-N4 at an inclined angle and CO is physically adsorbed above the side of the dangling O atom. As CO approaches O2, the OO bond is elongated. The first CO2 is formed by overcoming the potential barrier of 0.75 eV and releasing the reaction energy of 3.54 eV. Then the second CO2 is formed in Fe-N4 and more reaction energy is released (see Fig. S8(d)). At the same time, we also calculated the ER1 mechanism of Fe-C4 (Tang et al. studied the most favorable mechanism for CO catalysis by undoped Fe-C4 catalyst is ER1 [71]), and the reaction energy barrier is as high as 0.86 eV (Fig. S9), which is higher than that of the previous catalysts. In summary, the rate-determining step (RDS) of Fe-CxNy in the ER1 reaction mechanism differs depending on the N coordination number and is superior to that of the undoped Fe-C4 catalyst. A single-atom Fe catalyst with three coordinated N atoms only needs to overcome an energy barrier of 0.69 eV to carry out the CO oxidation reaction. 3.3.2 ER2 mechanism The reaction mechanism of ER2 is expressed by the following equations: (8) CO+O2*→CO3* (9) CO3*→CO2+O* (10) O*+CO→CO2 After a comprehensive transition state search and geometry optimization, we found that CO cannot react with the active O2 molecules on Fe-C3N to form CO3 intermediates, which is consistent with literature reports. The high selectivity of Fe-N4 for CO suggests that it is more difficult to generate CO3 intermediates on Fe atoms, which also agrees with our calculations. Hence, only the ER2 mechanism of Fe-C2N2 and Fe-CN3 catalysts for the catalytic combustion of CO is discussed in this paper. The energy distribution of CO and the corresponding reaction paths in the ER2 mechanism of Fe-C2N2 and FeCN3 are shown in Fig. 5 . Fe-CN2 has a higher affinity for O2 than Fe-CN3. In Fig. 5(b), CO physisorption above preadsorbed O2 is designated IS. O2 is fully activated and the OO bond is broken with the proximity of CO. The bond length of Fe-O is shortened from 1.85 Å to 1.65 Å. Then a carbonate-like intermediate (CO3) is generated through a potential barrier of 0.79 eV, and the bond length between the C-terminus of CO and the broken O atom is 1.35 Å. At the same time, the bond length of CO was extended by 0.07 Å compared with that of free CO. The process is an exothermic reaction, releasing a reaction energy of 3.38 eV. Interestingly, decomposition of carbonate-like (CO3) into chemisorbed O atoms and free CO2 requires overcoming an energy barrier of up to 0.93 eV, which implies that the rate-limiting step of the Fe-C2N2 single-atom catalyst on the ER2 mechanism is the decomposition of CO3. Compared to Fe-CN3, only 0.09 eV is required for CO and preadsorbed O2 to generate CO3 via the ER2 mechanism, and the dissociation energy barrier for CO3 is 0.8 eV (see Fig. 5(c)). Although Fe-CN3 is more prone to the ER2 mechanism than Fe-C2N2, the energy barrier for the rate-limiting step is still relatively high overall. 3.3.3 LH mechanism The energy distribution of the LH mechanism of Fe-CxNy is shown in Fig. 6 (a). The LH mechanism can be expressed as: (11) CO*+O2*→OCOO* (12) OCOO*→CO2+O* (13) O*+CO→CO2 Both CO and O2 are adsorbed on the catalyst and then the reaction between the adsorbed CO and O2 occurs through certain energy barriers to form intermediates (OCOO). The dissociation of OCOO to CO2 and the chemisorption of O atoms also require overcoming energy barriers. The adsorption energy of the tetra-N-coordinated monatomic Fe catalyst for CO is almost twice that of O2, which means that the possibility of Fe-N4 coadsorption of CO and O2 is extremely small and thus the reaction through the LH mechanism is difficult. This is comparable to theoretical studies in the literature [72]. We have also found that O2 cannot be coadsorbed on Fe atoms when the geometry of CO and O2 coadsorption is fully optimized. For this reason, we did not investigate the LH mechanism of Fe-N4 in the present work. Taking Fe-CN3 as an example (the reaction path is shown in Fig. 6(b)), CO and O2 coadsorbed on Fe atoms are considered IS, where CO adsorbs at a tilted angle and O2 is parallel to the graphene substrate. During the reaction of CO with O2, O2 is activated, and the longest FeO bond breaks and rotates, bringing it close to the C atom of CO to form the OCOO intermediate, which is considered MS. The process of forming the OCOO intermediate is exothermic and does not require crossing of the potential barrier. An energy of 0.97 eV is exerted from IS through TS1 to MS, and the length of the OO bond extends from 1.35 Å to 1.51 Å. Subsequently, the OO bond breaks and the Fe-C bond length is further elongated to provide the conditions for the dissociation of CO2. Then, by overcoming the free energy barrier of only 0.20 eV, the reaction readily passes from MS to FS via TS2. Residual O* reacts with the approaching CO to form CO2 with an energy barrier of only 0.42 eV. The reaction paths of Fe-C3N and Fe-C2N2 are shown in Figs. S10 and S11. An N-doped single-atom Fe catalyst catalyzing the CO oxidation reaction through the LH mechanism needs to overcome 0.70 eV, which may be related to the similar adsorption energies of Fe-C3N for CO and O2, corresponding to −1.52 eV and −1.50 eV, respectively. Intriguingly, with a low energy barrier (0.02 eV) in the second half of the reaction, the resulting OCOO intermediate dissociates into CO2 and adsorbs O atoms with almost no external force. It generates a reaction energy of 3.27 eV, which is very favorable for the reaction. The RDS of 0.35 eV for the reaction of CO with O2 catalyzed by Fe-C2N2 is superior to that of single-atom catalysts with a single N ligand. More surprisingly, the energy barrier for the dissociation of the intermediate to CO2 and adsorbed O is only 0.11 eV, which is a tiny energy barrier for the catalytic reaction. Based on the above analysis, the LH mechanism is friendly for Fe-CxNy catalysts, and the energy barriers of the reaction RDS are all reasonable. For Fe-C3N and Fe-C2N2, the RDS is the formation of OCOO at 0.70 eV and 0.35 eV, respectively, while for Fe-CN3 with three coordinated N atoms, the RDS is the dissociation of OCOO with a reaction barrier of 0.20 eV. This indicates that different Fe-N and Fe-C coordination environments affect the catalytic performance. The more the number of N coordinations increases, the easier the intermediate formation. 3.3.4 TER mechanism Based on the above analysis, the TER mechanism of the CO oxidation reaction is feasible on Fe-CxNy. Two CO molecules are first presorbed onto the catalyst and O2 from the air attacks the CO, overcoming the potential barrier to combine with the C atoms of the two COs to form a five-membered ring intermediate (OCOOCO). Then OCOOCO dissociates synchronously into two CO2 molecules. This mechanism was first proposed in the h-BN catalyzed oxidation of CO by Mao et al. and can be expressed by the following equation [22]: (14) 2CO*+O2→OCOOCO* (15) OCOOCO*→2CO2 Here, we still take Fe-CN3 as an example. In Fig. 7 (a), IS is two preadsorbed CO molecules and an O2 molecule physically adsorbed on top of CO. MS is a cyclic OCOOCO intermediate adsorbed on Fe atoms. As O2 gradually approaches CO, the OO bond length is elongated from 1.24 Å to 1.27 Å. Two O atoms and two C atoms of CO form two CO bonds, resulting in the OCOOCO intermediate. The CO bond lengths in MS are 1.38 Å, and the OO bond length was extended to 1.47 Å. Forming two CFe bonds with the combination of O2 and CO, the bond lengths extend from 1.82 Å and 1.75 Å to 2.04 Å and 2.02 Å, respectively. The reaction energy barrier in this step is 0.67 eV. Subsequently, in the process from MS to FS, the OO bond breaks to form two OCO*, which dissociate into two CO2 simultaneously after 0.29 eV. The distances between carbon dioxide and iron atoms are 4.03 Å and 4.00 Å, respectively. Having an average adsorption energy of −0.19 eV, CO2 is weakly adsorbed and can be dissociated automatically at room temperature. Compared to the Fe catalyst with three N coordination numbers, the activity of Fe monoatomic catalysts for CO oxidation decreases when the number of N coordinations decreases to 1 or 2. From Fig. 7(b), the energy barrier of the monatomic catalyst with single-ligand N reaching MS after TS1 is 0.80 eV. When the N coordination number increases to 2, the first reaction energy barrier is as high as 1.22 eV. Notably, when the coordination number is 4, the energy barrier of the catalyst for CO oxidation is higher than that of the triple-ligand N and single-ligand N, which is 0.91 eV. This is actually related to the high selectivity of Fe-N4 for CO, and when the CO adsorption energy is high, the activation of two CO molecules by O2 to form a five-membered ring intermediate requires high energy, and the calculated results are complementary to theory. Obviously, the Fe-CxNy catalyst has a volcano peak shape oxidation activity law. Reasonable adjustment of the N coordination number can improve the oxidation activity of the catalyst. In an environment rich in CO, Fe-CN3 has a better catalytic oxidation activity for CO. Reaction pathways for Fe-C3N, Fe-C2N2 and Fe-N4 catalyzed CO oxidation are shown in Figs. S12–S14, respectively. 3.4 Activity comparison From the above analysis, it is clear that CO has the best oxidation activity on Fe-CN3, and the RDS through the LH mechanism is the dissociation of OCOO* with a Gibbs barrier of 0.20 eV, which is lower than that of the noble metal and other metal-doped catalysts (as shown in Table 2 ). Evidence of Fe-CN3 catalysts with ultrahigh catalytic activity and promising applications in CO catalytic combustion reactions. 4 Reaction kinetics on Fe-CxNy To investigate the effect of different temperatures on Fe-CxNy, we calculated the reaction rate constants of Fe-CxNy for CO oxidation by different mechanisms. The reaction rate constants for all Fe-based catalysts with different N coordination at 100–1000 K are shown in Fig. 8 . We found that the reaction rate constants increase with increasing temperature. This indicates that the increase in temperature can promote the catalytic ability of the Fe-CxNy catalyst for CO oxidation. In addition, at temperatures below room temperature, almost all reactions are strongly inhibited and unfavorable. It is noteworthy that Fe-C2N2 and Fe-CN3 can also react below room temperature via the LH mechanism. At 298 K, the reaction rate constants of Fe-C2N2 and Fe-CN3 are 1.26 × 107 cm3 molecule−1 s−1 (9.74 × 106 cm3 molecule−1 s−1) and 4.32 × 1012 cm3 molecule−1 s−1 (3.34 × 1012 cm3 molecule−1 s−1), respectively. This result is consistent with the previous calculation of the transition state energy barrier. Moreover, the Arrhenius Equation k=ATnexp(-E/RT) can be derived from Eq. (4). The values of A, n, and E for each basic reaction step are written in Table S2. These reaction constants will help to construct a complex reaction model on the catalyst surface. Turnover frequency (TOF) is an important criterion to judge the catalyst activity which can be further investigated for the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. According to Sebastian Kozuch [78], for exothermic reactions, the turnover frequency can be calculated by the following equation: (16) TOF = k B T h exp [ − Δ E / ( RT ) ] where kB is the Boltzmann constant and h represents the Planck constant. ΔE denotes the amount of standard state Gibbs free energy change between the transition state and the initial state. Table S3 shows that for Fe-CxNy catalysts at 298 K, the TOFs are 2.47 × 10−3, 2.06 × 103, 7.12 × 105 and 3.52 × 10−4 h−1, respectively. Obviously, the catalyst with three nitrogen ligands has the best turnover frequency. 5 Conclusion In this work, the oxidation activity and mechanism of the low-temperature catalytic combustion of CO over double -defective graphene Fe monoatomic catalysts under different coordination environments are systematically investigated using DFT calculations. Among all possible reaction mechanisms of Fe-CxNy catalysts, Fe-C3N tends to achieve LH mechanisms at an energy barrier of 0.70 eV. Fe-C2N2, similar to Fe-CN3, tends to undergo the LH mechanism with an energy barrier of 0.35 eV. Tetra-coordinated N atom Fe based catalysts tend to undergo ER1 and LH mechanisms and need to overcome a potential barrier of 0.91 eV. In all coordination environments, Fe-CxNy immobilized by three coordination nitrogen atoms shows the highest CO oxidation performance with only a barrier of 0.20 eV. It is necessary to select different catalysts according to different environments to achieve efficient oxidation. Fe-CN3 exhibits superior catalytic performance in both O2-rich and CO-rich environments, as well as in environments with comparable concentrations of both. Furthermore, we found that the increase in temperature favors the reaction proven by the rate constant calculation, and for the FeCN3 catalyst, the reaction rate constant is still large at low temperature, which means that this catalyst is expected to be an efficient nonprecious metal catalyst for low temperature catalytic combustion of CO. By combining the rate constant with the Arrhenius formula, some data of the kinetic model of the catalytic combustion reaction were obtained. In conclusion, the present work shows that Fe-CxNy can be used as an efficient and promising catalyst for the catalytic oxidation of CO with nonprecious metals. coredata.dc:description: Harmful carbon monoxide (CO) gas from vehicle exhaust and fossil fuel combustion seriously affects the ecological environment and human health, although this issue can be effectively solved by low-temperature catalytic combustion. Herein, an Fe and N codoped double vacancy graphene catalyst (Fe-CxNy) for the low-temperature catalytic combustion of CO is proposed, and the mechanism of the CO catalytic combustion reaction over the catalyst is systematically investigated by using density function theory (DFT). Four oxidation mechanisms, including Eley–Rideal (ER1 and ER2), Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) and Termolecular Eley–Rideal (TER), were compared in terms of oxidation pathways and energy distribution. All the results indicate that Fe-CxNy catalysts have efficient catalytic activity. The Fe-CN3 catalyst with the predominant LH reaction mechanism showed the best performance for the catalytic combustion of CO with only 0.20 eV, which was comparable to that of noble metals. The rate constant calculations further demonstrate that Fe-CN3 exhibits excellent catalytic performance at low temperatures. This work not only provides a theoretical basis for the design and development of low-temperature catalytic combustion CO catalysts, but also provides data support for the kinetic model of CO combustion reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical study on the reaction kinetics of CO oxidation by nitrogen-doped graphene catalysts with different ligand structures
